titlestmt.sponsor: This collection-level EAD record is a product of the Philadelphia Area Consortium of Special Collections Libraries (PACSCL) Consortial Survey Initiative, which was funded by the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: Machine-readable finding aid generated in EAD from data in the PACSCL Consortial Survey Database on 12/21/2012. Modified by Dot Porter in 2017.

bioghist.p: Thomas Morris Longstreth (b. 1886) was an author. His works were published in the Christian Science Monitor and other publications. His books include Knowing the Weather, The Silent Force, The Laurentians, The Catskills, and The Lake Superior Country. Charles Wharton Stork (b. 1883) was a poet and teacher who lived in Philadelphia. His published volumes include Hearts and Voices, On Board Old Ironsides, and Sea and Bay. He was also a translator and anthololgist of Swedish poetry. He taught English Literature for 25 years at Harcum College, Bryn Mawr, Pennsylvania, and lectured on poetry around the country and overseas. He was a founder of Contemporary Verse magazine, and served as president of the Poetry Society of America and of the Browning Society in Philadelphia.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of correspondence between T. Morris Longstreth and Charles Wharton Stork, from 1901 to 1968. The majority of the letters are from Longstreth to Stork. The letters discuss the writing output and careers of both men, with comments and suggestions passing back and forth. The letters occasionally touch on family matters and events of the day, but their main focus in on the craft of writing. The letters include a number of poems by Stork, and several by Longstreth. There are newspaper clippings of pieces by Longstreth and several clippings of reviews. The collection also includes a small amount of correspondence between Longstreth and Stork's wife Lisl.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

relatedmaterial.p: Related material may be found in the following collections: Syracuse University: Charles Wharton Stork Papers, Special Collections Research Center, Syracuse University Library
